Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Efficacy of Cricoid Pressure during Rapid Sequence Induction

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either cricoid pressure (n=20) or simulated cricoid pressure (n=20)

Participants.evidence: This randomised controlled trial included 40 participants undergoing elective surgery requiring general anaesthesia.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either cricoid pressure (n=20) or simulated cricoid pressure (n=20) during RSI.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the prevalence of aspiration, measured by visual inspection, pepsin detection, or radiographic changes.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either cricoid pressure (n=20) or simulated cricoid pressure (n=20)

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis approach was not specified, and the number of participants analysed in each group was not detailed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The study found no significant difference in the primary outcome between the cricoid pressure and control groups.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
